This Memorial Day week, we're remembering recently deceased men and women who served in uniform during World War II.
Today, Tuskegee Airmen George Porter.
He died this winter at age 91.
The Tuskegee Airmen were African-Americans and they were the first to fly in support combat planes.
Chief Master Sergeant Porter was a crew chief, aircraft maintenance mechanic with the airmen.
In a 2007 TV documentary, he spoke about the racial prejudice that made his job difficult.
We did things that we weren't supposed to do as the mechanics on the flight line because when we would order parts, they wouldn't send us the parts, so we learned how to repair our own parts.
Porter often shared his experiences with younger members of his chapter of the Tuskegee Airmen in Sacramento.
One of them was Walter Suggs.
What they would when they come back with a hole in the aircraft, and if it was large enough, they would go out and measure it.
And then they would go into the mess hall or something like that, where you could find these empty cans.
They would take them, cut them up into a patch.
And they would go out and rivet it to the aircraft.
Those lessons learned during the war stayed with Porter and he passed them onto his daughter, Linda.
Don't let anybody tell you that you will fail.
